_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Seal pots, pumps, tanks, piping, receivers, reactors, relief valves, deluge pump
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The process consists of and ethylene oxide (EO) rail car, a propylene oxide (PO) tankwagon, two centrifugal pumps (one for EO and one for PO) for transferring to and from an EO bulk storage tank (T22), a PO bulk storage tank (T-19), three intermediate receivers (day tanks), two positive displacement pumps for transferring EO/PO between the intermediate receivers and from the intermediate receivers to the reactors, three reactors and the piping connecting the above-mentioned components.

Common to all components of the system is a twenty point organic vapor monitoring device that alarms at 7.5 ppm.  Three water cannons and sprinkler system are present to supress fire and vapor release.  

The temperature of the EO railcar is monitored twice a day.  A catch plate is postioned under the EO railcar contain small leaks.  

The centifugal pumps have double mechanical seals with a low barrier fluid shutoff, a high and low amperage shutoff, and a high temperture shutoff. 

Bulk EO storage tank (T-22) and Bulk storage tank (T-19) have high and low level alarms, high and low pressure alarms, and a high temperature alarm.  T-22 is positioned in a concrete bunker and is also equipped with its own water deluge system.  T-19 is positoned within a concrete diked area.  

Intermediate storage vessels are equipped with high and low pressure alarms and high temperature alarms.  These vessels are also protected with a water sprinkler system.  

Pumps to the reactors are equipped with bypasses that operate automatically should the pumps experience high pressure.  

Reactors are positioned on load cells and are equipped with high temperature and high pressure alarms.  

Piping used for EO and PO is schedule 80 pipe capable of withstanding corrosion.  The piping is painted and in open areas insultated as well to protect the piping from the heat of the sun.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental release and emergency response policies:

An emergency situation, by definition, occurs unexpectedly.  Whatever its form, it may present a potentially serious threat to company operations, health and safety of employees and the surrounding community.  Some emergencies are governed by strict federal, state and local regulations.  Therefore it is essential that all employees working at this site be aware of potential emergency situations, to plan for them, and to follow emergency procedures should an emergency occur.

The purpose of these procedures are to provide information and establish guidelines for responding to emergencies.  Our procedures include requirements for emergency notification to outside agencies, emergency communications within the plant, evacuation plans, and steps for implementing response activities.  

The procedures are divided into separate sections for quick reference and easy access to vital information.  These sections include plan implementation, emergency equipment and personnel responsibilities, facility layout, emergency procedures, emergency contacts and communication, and spill management.  All employees are expected to become familiar with emergency procedures and are trained on the procedures on an annual basis.

The Janesville plant is seriously committed to operating safely.  The plant has a comprehensive set of emergency response procedures.  We have a fully trained emergency response team on hand capable of responding to chemical releases.  We also participate as an active member of the county LEPC.  Site officials work closely with the local fire department and safety and environmental consultants to help insure the facility complies with all permits and environmental regulations.

Facility operations:

The facility is known as a manufacturer of surfactants.  The principal products include food ingredients, Kosher specialty oils, fabric softeners, and specialty surfactants.  These ingredients are used in food, cosmeti

cs, pharmaceuticals, and personal care products.  The facility is committed to protecting human health and the environment and hazardous materials are managed in accordance with applicable health, safety and environmental regulations.  

This facility is subject to Risk Management Planning.  

Prevention program:  accidental chemical-specific releases:

Our facility is subject to Process Safety Management (PSM).  As a result we have written operating procedures that are used to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances.  The equipment used to process with these regulated substances is equipped with alarms for pressure, temperature, and hazardous vapors to alert personnel of emergency conditions.  These alarms allow personnel to safely and quickly respond to conditions like a chemical release before a release has off-site consequences.  The facilty has an active security program and works closely with the local authorities in preplanning and prevention of chemical releases.  

Five year accident history:

There have been no releases from this site in the past 5 years that have resulted in off-site consequences.

Emergency response program:

Our facility has a highly trained emergency response team that equipped to quickly control and mitigate small releases of regulated substances at the facility before releases become too big.  Team members practice responding to potential  response scenarios of regulated substances as part of their annual training requirement.  This training is led by the on-site Health, Safety and Environmental Manager.  Emergency drills are conducted and detailed training on the facility contingency plan is provided to all employees.  The Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) Manager serves as a member of the Rock County LEPC.   The HSE Manager coordinates preplanning of emergency services with the LEPC, local health care facilities, police department and various fire departments.  

For large scale releases of regulated substances thi

s facility would rely upon 911 emergency response services provided by the local and regional fire departments.  It is estimated that the fire department could arrive at our facility in a matter of 15 minutes.

Planned changes to improve safety:

There are plans to upgrade O-rings on several of our reactor agitator seals from Kalrez to Teflon.

We plan to upgrade our organic vapor monitor to include more modern electronics and sensors.

We plan to extend our alarm announcers to other buildings to allow more people to monitor chemical operations.

We are inviting officers from the city police department to tour our facility to understand the hazards of our facility.
